Award.AwardTitle: Project BUILD (Building Using an Interactive Learning Design)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by bringing together youth (grades 2-5), their families, librarians, and professional engineers in an informal environment centered on engaging youth with age-appropriate, technology-rich STEM learning experiences fundamental to the engineering design process. The overarching aim is to better understand how youth's learning preferences or dispositions relate to their STEM learning experiences. It also seeks to build community members' capacity to inspire and educate youth about STEM careers. The project team includes the Space Science Institute's (SSI) National Center for Interactive Learning (NCIL), the University of Virginia (UVA) and the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE). This team builds on the scope and reach of a prior NSF-funded project called the STAR Library Education Network (STAR_Net). As an extension of this prior work, Project BUILD will collaborate with 6 public libraries (3 urban and 3 rural) and their local ASCE Branches. Two libraries have been selected to serve as pilots: High Plains Public Library in Colorado and the African-American Research Library and Cultural Center in Florida. All partner libraries will develop a plan for recruiting participants from groups currently underrepresented in STEM professions.

Project BUILD's specific aims are to 1) Engage underserved audiences, 2) Build the capacity of participating librarians and ASCE volunteers, 3) Increase interest and engagement in STEM activities for youth in grades 2-5 and their families, and 4) Conduct a comprehensive education research project. Program components include the following: 1) Community Dialogue Events, 2) a Professional Development Program for partner librarians and ASCE volunteers, and 3) Development of a Technology-rich Programming Kit and Circulating STEM Kit program. Two research questions will be addressed: 1) What common factors might identify youth who engage in project activities and what factors might differentiate between youth who continue with program engagement and those who do not? and 2) What programmatic factors (i.e. design and composition of program activities, library recruitment, librarian engagement, professional engineer engagement, etc.) might influence youth's initial and continued engagement in project activities as well as youth's reported future career interests? An external evaluation will investigate the quality of the project's process as well as its impact and effectiveness. Benefits to the participating libraries' communities, library and engineering professionals, and the education community will be achieved through 1) Community Dialogue events; 2) Library and Librarian Outreach; 3) ASCE Outreach; and 4) Publication of Research and Evaluation results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of Project BUILD was to increase youths' awareness of and motivation to pursue STEM-related educational and career pathways, especially for youth from rural and/or geographically isolated areas and populations traditionally underrepresented in STEM.

Two libraries and their partners from the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) were selected to serve as pilots: High Plains Library District in Colorado and the African American Research Library and Cultural Center in Florida. An additional four library/ASCE pairs (2 urban and 2 rural) were selected early in 2018, including, Anchorage Public Library (Alaska), Cuyahoga County Public Library (Ohio), Kanawha County Public Library (West Virginia), and Free Library of Philadelphia (Pennsylvania). These six library/ASCE partners facilitated engaging engineering learning experiences through hands-on activities, circulating kits, virtual programs and more.

STAR Net's Community Dialogue framework (http://www.starnetlibraries.org/deia/community-dialogues/) was refined to better understand and build community members capacity to inspire and help youth learn about engineering and STEM careers. Project BUILD libraries hosted Dialogue events to engage in conversations with representatives from their local communities, including ASCE volunteers, with an emphasis on including representatives from groups underrepresented in STEM professions. Conversations included STEM learning, career opportunities, and equitable library access.

Library staff and engineers received online and in-person training on the project's Ready, Set, Create hands-on activities. They became a "guide on the side" instead of a "sage on the stage". This approach utilizes questioning that accesses prior knowledge and experiences; lively discussions that encourage deep and open thinking; and a fun, engaging environment in which there are no wrong answers. See http://www.starnetlibraries.org/resources/guide-on-the-side/ for more details.

The Research Team used their FOCIS framework that explores seven different types of active learning commonly used by STEM-based youth programs. Analysis involved an iterative review of the curriculum for each type of learning activity, with each pass through the curriculum looking specifically for activities related to each of the seven types of active learning. 

Because of COVID-19, the Project BUILD program pivoted to provide partner libraries and others a virtual engagement program called Dream Build Create in partnership with ASCE. This program (in November 2020) included virtual screenings of the award-winning documentary, Dream Big: Engineering Our World along with virtual Dream Team panels featuring diverse groups of engineers. 

Research Results. Including subject matter experts (SMEs), like volunteer engineers, in out-of-school-time (OST) STEM programs is a method for enriching the experience of youth participants. Public libraries play an increasingly larger role in the OST arena. This study looked at the alignment in active learning preferences between youth and program facilitators and found that participating program youth and engineers were much more closely aligned than librarians. Alignment between youth-program participants and SME program facilitators has the potential to create additional connections enriching the program experience for youth.

Evaluation Results. Most library staff and engineers reported that they are very likely to facilitate or co-facilitate additional engineering-related youth programming in the future. All library staff were interested in continuing to circulate their existing kits, and many expressed interest in creating additional STEM-related kits to circulate in the future. A key part of the Project BUILD professional development strategy focused on increasing confidence in both library staff and ASCE volunteers in facilitating STEM programs. Throughout the project, engineers played an active role in most Project BUILD programs. 

Library staff and engineers found their relationship with their partners to be valuable and felt that they and their organizations benefited from the partnership. The presence of diverse engineers who provided their experience and content knowledge helped library staff feel more comfortable conducting STEM programming and made engineering-related careers more accessible to patrons. Library staff provided expertise in working with youth and led program planning to reduce the burden on volunteer engineers. 

Library staff and engineers had increased interest, knowledge, and confidence in facilitating engineering-related programs with youth after their experience with the project. Library staff gained confidence and knowledge in offering STEM-related programming and gained a better understanding of engineering. Engineers learned about facilitating activities with young children and enjoyed reaching new audiences, especially underserved audiences. 

Programs were able to effectively reach diverse and underserved participants by reaching out into the communities to provide programming and facilitating programs with engineers from diverse backgrounds. Some partner libraries facilitated Project BUILD programs at or with community centers or other non-profit organizations that served diverse patrons. All Project BUILD partner libraries circulated engineering-related kits that allowed them to reach audiences that otherwise might not have had access to this type of programming. Project BUILD programs often involved engineers from diverse backgrounds; engineers noted that they were able to interact with more diverse youth than they typically did in large part because of the library's connection to the community.
